Ask HN: So what IS the end game for any WW3 scenario?
text:
Given today's announcements about Russia pulling out of START, I got to thinking about whether it makes a real difference. I mean, once any one of the major atomic powers decides to "go for broke" I don't see any way that they don't all have to use most of their missiles. Even if it's only two of them initially, it's not likely any of the others want to wait to see if one of the others has enough left to impose their will on the rest.

At which point - then what? None of the major atomic powers has enough (if any) missiles left to be much of a deterrent, and none of them will have armed forces that are any more prepared to do an Atlantic or Pacific crossing and invasion than they are now. So it's just that much worse for everyone?

title: Show HN: Ask ChatGPT questions about any Website, PDF or Word doc
text:
Here's the home page: https://app.conifer.chat

I built this example using semantic search + GPT-3 to make files conversational regardless of whether they fit within GPT-3's token limit. Enter a website url or upload a document then just ask for a summarization or any other questions about the document. Behind the scenes the document is parsed and I'm using embeddings to pull out context for GPT-3 when asking your question. Summarization seems to work pretty well but I've found it to really shine when asking specifics about a document that ChatGPT wouldn't be answer on it's own. I'd love any feedback or thoughts on other things that would be interesting to do with this app (Reddit bot?, Chrome extension?). Thanks!

Example Articles:

How Our Reality May Be a Sum of Possible Realities https://app.conifer.chat/threads/68087fd1-a9d8-43ad-a7bb-f41...

Building a smart mirror - Raspberry Pi https://app.conifer.chat/threads/02a0af22-03f0-4fd5-8724-b1d...

President Biden State of the Union Address - CNN https://app.conifer.chat/threads/b24cb5fb-f973-4ba9-b92f-391...

Ask HN: What do you like or dislike about team/org domain name management?
text:
I've used the two most popular domain name providers, GoDaddy and Namecheap, to manage domains. Both leave a lot to be desired, particularly around teams & permissions, that I'm considering to build a product around if others have similar problems. I'm curious if you have the same problems and what products you're already using to solve said problems.

Here's my list:

1. For eng orgs of 50+ people, I'd like to setup an org that folks can SSO into via Google/SAML/whatever to acquire new domains under said org. This would include tools like an approval workflow so that a security or purchasing person can approve requests to buy new domains.

2. I'd like to have better ACLs for managing the DNS records of said domains. I think AWS, Google, Azure, etc. have some levels of this in their products, but setting it up isn't for the faint of heart. I'd like to see something that's more "baked" and simper to manage permissions around administering DNS records. e.g. I could have a policy for `*.example.dev` domains that let folks grab whatever sub-domain, but maybe only a few people can manage `www.example.com` records with the approval of another admin (like the two-key approach to launching ICBMs)

3. I want a CLI. It's insane that I have to fire up a browser when I want to change DNS records.

I think https://dnsimple.com/ comes the closest, and possibly solves most or all of these problems. Its really hard to tell from the demo or trial, which is why I'm asking here.
